slide.text: USMS University™ Quick Start Training Point of Sale Equipment And Processing Solutions

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. In The Beginning…
Transactions were done the old-fashioned way with paper drafts, floor-limit auto-approvals, and telephone authorizations. Merchants had to check a paper Card-Recovery Bulletin to see if a card were still valid. New technology-Electronic Data Capture or EDC was introduced in the 1980s which used Point of Sale Terminals to process transactions. Today, there’s a virtual plethora of processing devices and methods. Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point of Sale Terminals
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. POS Terminals are used for: Reading magnetic cards Reading SMART cards Reading Contactless RFID cards Capturing all necessary transaction information Performing electronic authorizations Completing sales and credits (swiped and keyed) Printing receipts Reporting on transaction activity Facilitate transactions using credit cards, debit cards, gift cards, EBT, checks, and more. Point of Sale Terminals
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Today’s Market Leaders in POS Terminals Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Setting up a POS device:
POS terminals capture and transmit sensitive information to banks and third party processors. Setting up a POS device is a technical process which USMS™ usually handles on behalf of its agents. Once account is opened by USMS, the next step is to “program the terminal” whether a new terminal or one already owned by the merchant. For each merchant a special software application is loaded on top of the terminal’s operating system, based on merchant requirements such as retail, restaurant with tips, salon, rental car, etc. After the download, the merchant’s transactions are now routed to the new merchant account.
Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Processing Platforms, Programs and Terminal Compatibility:
POS terminals and applications must be certified to work on specific processing platforms. Vital, Global Payments, First Data are some of the major processors. A terminal or application that works on First Data, will not necessarily work on Global. Application parameters vary with business type, merchant needs, IP versus dial up, etc. For example: Retail stores use different applications than restaurants, restaurants with tips use different application than restaurants without tips (e.g. a fast food restaurant). Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Processing Platforms, Programs and Terminal Compatibility:
USMS publishes and updates a Terminal Matrix showing specific terminals, applications and platforms the terminal is certified with. Familiarize yourself with this document and study any updates. Available on agent web site.
Additional applications such as gift cards, check conversion, or guarantee must also be certified with the terminal, credit card processor or gift card, or check guarantee vendor. See Terminal Matrix. Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Installation Procedures at USMS:
USMS approves account USMS builds file application Terminal is loaded and tested on-site Terminal is shipped to the merchant or agent For Merchant/owner terminal reprograms- application is built at USMS, tested, “staged” for downloading by agent or merchant, then downloaded by dialing into the USMS download center If needed, the terminal can be shipped back to USMS to be downloaded USMS technical department or agent trains the merchant on use and runs test transactions
Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Troubleshooting Terminal Issues, find out or ensure the following:
The merchant should have a dedicated phone line –so that an uninterrupted download can be done. Merchants that use the same phone line for card transactions that they speak on often run into difficulties with interrupted transactions. Dial-up POS terminals require analog phone lines (POTS: plain old telephone service) and do not work properly on digital phone lines without a specific filter installed. An alternative to dial-up terminals are IP terminals that work on DSL or other IP enabled connections
Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Types of Terminals:
ALL-PURPOSE TERMINALS perform basic functions such as Sale, Void, Credit, Auth-Only and Force. They usually have built-in thermal printers and PIN-pads. Examples: VeriFone VX Series Hypercom 4200 Series
Point-of-Sale Terminals

Types of Terminals: FULL-FEATURE TERMINALS-These machines hold more than one application (a.k.a. multi-application terminals) best used when: More than one merchant account is loaded (such as hair salon with many stylists each using their own account). Other applications are used for Gift Cards or Check Guarantee or Check Conversion on the same terminal. Examples: VeriFone Vx510LE Hypercom T4205

Examples: VeriFone Vx570 Hypercom T4220 Dejavoo X8 Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: Point-of-Sale Terminals
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. WIRELESS TERMINALS: There are merchants who need mobility and work best with a wireless terminal: Limos and taxis Carpet Cleaners Contractors Flea market merchants Pizza delivery With wireless terminals merchants get real-time authorizations resulting in lower risk, faster funds, lower rates and fewer charge backs than they would if they keyed transactions. Examples of Wireless Terminals Include: Verifone Vx670 Nurit 8020 Hypercom M 4230 Way Systems 5000 Point-of-Sale Terminals

slide.title: PIN-Pads
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. PIN PADS: Merchants require a PIN (Personal Identification Number) Pad in order to process PIN Debit Transactions. There are two types of PIN Pads- internal (built into terminal) and external (separate peripheral). External PIN-pads make the transactions easier for the cardholders and merchants. PIN Pads are securely encrypted and in a secure environment. If a merchant is reprogramming with USMS and has a PIN Pad, the PIN Pad must be shipped to USMS to be re-encrypted, or USMS will exchange their current PIN Pad for one in stock. Examples of PIN Pads include: Verifone 1000SE Hypercom S9
PIN-Pads
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Verifone MX830 Multi-lane Retail PIN-Pad PIN-Pads

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Check Imagers and Readers
CHECK READERS (MICR READERS): Until recently the primary way to scan checks was to slide the check through a MICR (MICR = Magnetic Ink Character Recognition) Reader or Check Reader, which scans account data from checks, which is printed in magnetic ink.
CHECK IMAGERS: Create and store check images that can be converted into electronic transactions and forwarded for remittance (called Check Conversion).
With new technology and laws governing electronic check presentment (Check 21) Check Imagers are preferred because of scanning and storing-making images available for retrieval.
Check Imagers plug into most modern terminals. It is a simple and fast process to scan the check. The check is then handed back to the check writer, while the scanned check is cleared electronically. MICR Readers
Check Imager

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. POS Software POS Software: PC-based POS terminal. Process payments using a regular PC. Recurring billing cycles, import large transaction lists. Integrates with PC-based cash registers (POS Systems). Capable of handling swiped and keyed transactions.

slide.title: Payment Gateways
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Payment Gateways Payment Gateways were initially created to process e-commerce transactions Today Payment Gateways are used for a variety of processing solutions: E-commerce transactions As virtual terminal for manually entered transactions Hi speed swipe over IP transactions Integrated payment solution with various POS software Wireless connectivity As terminal host software (front-end) Use for a variety of specialty services- e-check, recurring billing, ACH, fraud detection, convenience fees and more

slide.title: Payment Gateways
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Payment Gateways How Internet Merchants Accept Cards: Live E-Commerce transactions are performed on-line with a payment gateway Gateways are usually integrated to “shopping carts”- and pull transaction data from the cart USMS offers a variety of gateways providing compatibility with most shopping carts Popular Payment Gateways include: Authorize.net USA E-Pay E-Processing Network USMS Gateway POSLinx

slide.title: Payment Gateways
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Payment Gateways Card numbers are entered via an on-line payment page or manually by merchant via “Virtual Terminal”: Manually enter mail order/telephone order transactions. Most payment gateways automatically close batches at night and send transaction data to the processor for settlement. User can set for manual batching. Today all Payment Gateways must be PCI Level I secure.

slide.title: Payment Gateways
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Payment Gateways Payment gateways provide numerous options for processing all types of transactions: Accept e-checks on your web site: Electronic checks allow for one-time check payment on-line Link to wireless devices such as I-Phone, smart phones or wireless terminals Recurring billing for credit card and ACH: Excellent service for membership billing, health clubs, rents, etc. Fraud prevention software: Scores transactions and identifies likelihood of a fraudulent transaction that could result in a costly charge back Consumer Convenience fee billing capability (required for government processing) with GovTeller’s POSLinx gateway Check with Agent support for which gateways are recommend for which applications

slide.title: Payment Gateways
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Payment Gateways Gateway History:
U.S. Merchant Systems was the first reseller of Authorize.net in 1997 and Authorize.net has been a preferred vendor ever since. U.S. Merchant Systems was the founder of IntelliPay, another popular payment gateway.

Point of Sale Systems Integrated Point of Sale Systems: Computerized cash registers for specialized industries: Retail Restaurants Night Clubs Multiple functions: Inventory control Menu ordering “Pay at the Table” feature Inexpensive paging system for calling patrons when table is ready Client CRM Cash register Payment processing device

slide.title: Point of Sale Systems
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Point of Sale Systems Used by desirable high-end low-risk merchants. Often uses POS Software or gateway to integrate with processors. Software used can be for dial up or IP transactions Usually serviced and supported by a Value-Added Reseller. Alliance with VARs can get you access to these merchants.

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. IVR and Voice Authorizations VOICE AUTHORIZATIONS
The main reason Voice Authorizations are used today are:
POS Terminal temporarily out of service. Merchants obtain Auth Codes by calling in to get the Voice Authorization and when the terminal is back on-line then enter the transactions for settlement.
Remote Access –Merchant would like to accept a bankcard but is not near their POS Terminal.
Call Center Message – Occasionally the merchant is required to call our “Call Center”. This can be for a fraudulent card, or Issuer wants information from merchant and/or cardholder.

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. INTERACTIVE VOICE RESPONSE (IVR) a.k.a. TOUCHPHONE
Voice Authorizations do not capture and settle transactions. IVR is a feature that gives merchants the options to perform a completed Sale, Voids, Returns/Credits Authorization Only, and capture and settlement for funding using the telephone keypad. IVR and Voice Authorizations
